Award.AwardTitle: CCRI: Planning: Collaborative Research: Planning to Develop a Low-Power Computer Vision Platform to Enhance Research in Computing Systems

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a planning grant to investigate how to develop a research infrastructure for investigating energy-efficient computer vision. Computer vision is a set of technologies for understanding image or video. These technologies are essential in many applications, such as autonomous vehicles and airport security. Some vision systems need to be energy-efficient because they use batteries, for example, drones and mobile phones. This infrastructure is planned to be available for researchers to experiment and evaluate their solutions. The evaluation includes the success rates of identifying different types of objects, the speed, and the energy consumption. The infrastructure has three major components: (1) video taken by drones, (2) vision system analyzing the data, (3) power meter. It will be designed for a wide range of vision problems. It will also include a referee system which automates the entire evaluation process.

There are many beneficial applications for low-power computer vision, for example, lightweight cameras that may provide safety for the vision impaired, wearable cameras that may improve factory safety or perform inventory analysis, and cameras for observing wildlife. The planning grant is to assess the needs of such an infrastructure for academia and industry. This team will actively engage the research community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project creates a new planning research infrastructure for low-power computer vision. The infrastructure is available for researchers to submit their vision solutions online through a website and can evaluate the success rates of the vision solutions, the execution time, and the energy consumption. The infrastructure is designed for a wide range of vision problems from drone video, including (1) constructing three-dimensional geometries of objects, (2) detecting and tracking multiple moving objects, (3) segmentation of multiple moving objects, and (4) re-identifying people. To fulfill the goal, Duke team developed two major components of the proposed new infrastructure: power meter and reference system that can automate the entire evaluation process. There are 20,000 test images from 200 classes in the used dataset. Test images are stored in the referee laptop and retrieved by participants? devices through a router. The results are uploaded to our referee laptop through the network. After a user log in, the power meter starts to measure the power consumption. The power meter stops after 10 minutes or the user finishes processing all the images and logs out.

The project fulfilled an urgent need for a common infrastructure for evaluation and comparison in low-power computer vision. It also accelerates innovation in low-power computer vision by providing a clear research direction of efficient neural network design and porting in resource-constrained embedded systems. The developed infrastructure has been widely used in the low-power computer vision challenges and other competitions organized by the PIs. The work also generated a set of training, validation, and testing data used for drone-based low-power computer vision contests.
